div.p: I have shipped to EM Clare of Hamilton 1 barrel of the finest coffee 1 of the finest sugar and one of Molasses on board of the Lohunton.

The papers contain an order aproving Jackson to the Utah service. This will prevent him staying with us as long as he caputed. I hope to get off on the 1st of February, and stopping two days at my farm, will reach home about the 12th. Tell Jackson not to leave until he sees me. My object in being here is to effect a money arrangement by which I will settle all my debt on the Mississippi plantation. This I think will be offorted in a day or two, though the times are hard and nothing of the sort can be done without paying too much.
When I left my place all were well except Benjamin, who had hurt his leg. The inflammation had fallen into his eyes.
My tunes in Tennessee were not paid, but the collector promised to wait until my return. They are enormous and would make a revolution in any other country but ours.

If the Hermitage Military school passes it will increase the value of our land, but will not really benefit any body but the chicken raisers and the shop dealers. I am opposed to the whole scheme as far as the public intent is to affected by it, but shall say nothing about it. If it increases the value of the land I proposed to sell McFarlane I shall be on the look out for the favorable moment to get rid of it.
Tell WM and Stockly to hold on to their cotton. It is obliged to sell higher in the course of six weeks, but even to day it would command 10 cents in this market.

David had better work out the session with Crofs, who is a good teacher. When I get home, I will try some new plan to get a teacher for Martin, Hen, & Haty to all of whom remember me affectionately, not forgetting David & Lewis.
With kind regards to your sister Kate and to Rachel, believe me always
